article.title: Influence of parameterized small-scale gravity waves on the migrating diurnal tide in Earth's thermosphere

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the difference field (EXP1-EXP0) in Figure 1c primarily illustrate?
choices: The increase in atmospheric density due to GW effects.
The change in atmospheric temperature due to GW effects.
The contraction of the thermosphere due to GW effects.
The increase in wind speed due to GW effects.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be observed about the zonal mean meridional wind during equinox in both cutoff and extended simulations?
choices: It is significantly stronger than the zonal wind at all altitudes.
It shows a strong westward flow in the lower thermosphere.
It is relatively weak compared to the solstitial circulation.
It peaks at high latitudes in the upper thermosphere.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the Northern Hemisphere, what is the primary impact of accounting for GWs on the zonal mean wind at high-latitude F2 region altitudes?
choices: Attenuation of the easterly wind, leading to a weaker poleward meridional circulation.
Strengthening of the easterly wind, leading to a stronger poleward meridional circulation.
Reversal of the wind direction from easterly to westerly.
Minimal change in the wind pattern.

multiple_choice_question.text: What significant dynamical effect do GWs primarily produce in the lower and upper thermosphere when allowed to propagate beyond the turbopause in the extended simulation (EXP1)?
choices: Westward zonal GW drag throughout the thermosphere.
Enhanced cooling in the lower thermosphere and heating in the upper thermosphere.
Eastward zonal GW drag in the lower and upper thermosphere.
Strong enhancement of the meridional GW forcing throughout the thermosphere.

multiple_choice_question.text: What causes the much larger maximum in diurnal tide amplitude observed in the upper thermosphere (above ~150 km) compared to the one in the low-latitude MLT?
choices: Downward propagating tides generated in the exosphere.
In-situ generated tides due to absorption of solar EUV radiation and ion-neutral coupling.
Upward propagating tides amplified by GW interactions in the thermosphere.
Enhanced molecular diffusion and thermal conduction in the upper thermosphere.
